1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies at the Stationary Source
1.1 Program Overview
Cold-Link Logistics Hattiesburg has developed and is implementing a consolidated program to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:
	Title 40 CFR Part 68EPAs Risk Management Program
	Title 29 CFR §1910.119OSHAs Process Safety Management Program

The Occupational Safety and Health Administrations (OSHA) process safety management (PSM) program has fourteen (14) major program elements. The Environmental Protection Agencys (EPA) risk management program (RMP) has the same major fourteen (14) program elements, but also has additional requirements for offsite consequence analyses and risk management plan submissions. Since the requirements in these two (2) regulations have substantial crossover, Cold-Link Logistics Hattiesburg has elected to develop and implement one (1) consolidated program to meet the requirements of both regulations. This consolidated program is referred to as the RMP/PSM program. 

1.2 Cold-Link Logistics Hattiesburg RMP/PSM Program Philosophy
Cold-Link Logistics Hattiesburg is not developing and implementing the RMP/PSM program to simply check a box or avoid regulatory penalties. Rather, Cold-Link Logistics Hattiesburg is committed to promoting the overall safety and health of employees, contractors, and visitors onsite. Furthermore, Cold-Link Logistics Hattiesburg has a duty to protect people and the environment in the surrounding community. Cold-Link Logistics Hattiesburg management and employees understand that a properly developed and implemented RMP/PSM program will help avoid accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia. While Cold-Link Logistics Hattiesburg, works hard to serve their clients, nothing takes precedence over maintaining the safety of the ammonia refrigeration system.

2. Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled
Cold-Link Logistics Hattiesburg is cold storage and freezer distribution center

located in Ellisville, MS which is twenty (20) miles north of Hattiesburg. In order to keep product at the desired temperature, Cold-Link Logistics Hattiesburg utilizes an industrial closed-loop ammonia refrigeration system. This ammonia refrigeration system is considered one (1) covered process having an ammonia inventory of approximately 30,000 lbs. Appendix A to Title 29 CFR §1910.119 lists the threshold quantity of anhydrous ammonia (CAS #: 7664-41-7) as 10,000 lbs. Since the quantity of the Ammonia Refrigeration System exceeds this quantity, it is subject to OSHAs Process Safety Management standard found in Title 29 CFR §1910.119.

The list of substances provided in Title 40 CFR §68.130 also lists the threshold quantity of anhydrous ammonia (CAS #: 7664-41-7) as 10,000 lbs. Since the quantity of the Ammonia Refrigeration System exceeds this quantity, it is subject to EPAs Risk Management Program standard found in Title 40 CFR Part 68.

Finally, the Program Level of the covered process needed to be determined. Since the worst-case release scenario for the Ammonia Refrigeration System would affect public receptors, it is not eligible for Program 1. Further, since the Ammonia Refrigeration System is subject to Title 29 CFR §1910.119 it is not eligible for Program 2. The result is that the Ammonia Refrigeration System is subject to Program 3 requirements.

3. General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
While Cold-Link Logistics Hattiesburg has a thorough RMP/PSM policy, a description of the requirements associated with each program element are summarized in the sections below.

3.1 Hazard Assessment
Coordinate with a consultant to complete a Hazard Assessment initially, every five (5) years, and if a change necessitates it. Maintain Cold-Link Logistics Hattiesburgs five-year accident history in the event that an incident meets the stringent criteria.

3.2 Process Safety Information	
Ensure all elements of Process Safety

Information are developed, accurate, in alignment with recognized and generally accepted good engineering practice (RAGAGEP), accessible, and updated when a change occurs.

3.3 Process Hazard Analysis
Either lead or hire a consultant to lead a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) initially, every five (5) years, and if a change necessitates it. Ensure the PHA scope, methodology, and team are sufficient and align with RAGAGEP. Ensure all PHA recommendations are addressed and resolution actions are documented. Ensure all PHA reports and recommendation resolutions and retained and accessible.

3.4 Operating Procedures
Either develop or hire a consultant to develop Operating Procedures (SOPs) which cover steps for each operating phase, operating limits, safety and health considerations, and safety systems and their functions. Make the SOPs accessible, keep them current, and certify them annually. Develop and implement safe work practices.

3.5 Training	
Ensure all operators receive initial and refresher training at least every three (3) years on an overview of the process and the SOPs. Properly document training activities.

3.6 Mechanical Integrity
Ensure all equipment in the covered process is included in the Mechanical Integrity program. Establish or hire a consultant to establish written procedures. Ensure operators are trained for process maintenance activities. Ensure the procedures and frequency for inspections and testing align with RAGAGEP. Ensure inspections and tests are properly documented. Ensure equipment deficiencies which are outside acceptable limits are corrected before further use or in a safe and timely manner (when necessary means are taken to assure safe operation). In the construction of new plants and equipment, oversee quality assurance through checks and inspections and verifying proper materials of construction.

3.7 Management of Change	
Oversee the implementation of the Management of Change procedures for all changes except replacements in kind.

.8 Pre-Startup Safety Review	
Oversee Pre-Startup Safety Review for new facilities and for modified facilities when the modification is significant enough to require a change in the Process Safety Information.

3.9 Compliance Audit
Either conduct or hire a consultant to conduct a Compliance Audit every three (3) years. Ensure at least one person knowledgeable in the process participates and that a written report is developed. Certify the Compliance Audit report. Ensure all Compliance Audit recommendations are addressed and resolution actions are documented. Retain the two (2) most recent Compliance Audit reports.

3.10 Incident Investigation
In the event of an accidental release or near-miss, initiate an incident investigation within 48 hours and assemble an investigation team. Develop a written report and address all findings from the report. Review the report with affected personnel and retain the report for five (5) years. Make any necessary accidental release notifications as soon as possible (within the first 15 minutes if possible). If an accidental release has offsite impacts, hold a public meeting within 90 days.

3.11 Employee Participation	
Oversee this written employee participation plan and ensure employees participate in the PHA and have access to necessary PSM program documentation.

3.12 Hot Work Permit
Ensure hot work permits are issued and observed for all hot work performed on or near covered processes.

3.13 Contractors	
Oversee contractors who work on or adjacent to covered processes (excluding those providing incidental services). Obtain and evaluate each contractors safety performance and programs. Inform contractors of known hazards onsite. Explain to contractors their responsibility under this program. Develop and implement safe work practices to control the entrance, presence, and exit of contractors to covered process areas. Periodically evaluate the performance of the contractor in fulfilling their obligations under this program.

5.4.2 Emergency Response Exercise Program
Since Cold-Link Logistics Hattiesburg is a non-responding stationary source, they need not develop an emergency response exercise program with field and tabletop exercises.
5.4.3 Alternative Means of Meeting Exercise Requirements
Cold-Link Logistics Hattiesburg may satisfy the requirement to conduct notification, field and/or tabletop exercises through: 
	Exercises conducted to meet other Federal, state or local exercise requirements, provided the exercise meets the requirements of the above bullet-point lists. 
	Response to an accidental release, provided the response includes the actions included in the bullet-point lists above, as appropriate. When used to meet field and/or tabletop exercise requirements, Cold-Link Logistics Hattiesburg will prepare an after-action report comparable to the exercise evaluation report, within 90 days of the incident.

5.5 Emergency Planning and Response
Cold-Link Logistics Hattiesburg will establish and implement an emergency action plan for the entire plant in accordance with the provisions of Title 29 CFR §1910.38. In addition, the emergency action plan will include procedures for handling small releases. Cold-Link Logistics Hattiesburg may also be subject to the hazardous waste and emergency response provisions contained in Title 29 CFR §1910.120 (a), (p) and (q).

6. Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Cold-Link Logistics Hattiesburg strives for and embraces a culture of openness to changeespecially as it relates to safety. Rather than seeking methods apart from the RMP/PSM program, Cold-Link Logistics Hattiesburg anticipates necessary changes becoming apparent as part of implementing the various elements and requirements of the process safety management and risk management program regulations. When a program activity is completed (e.g., process hazard analysis, compliance audit, mechanical integ

rity inspection), there are normally corresponding recommendations to improve the safety of the ammonia refrigeration system. Cold-Link Logistics Hattiesburg takes the findings from these activities and tracks all of them to completion. In rare circumstances, the recommendation may not be resolved in the manner prescribed by the recommendation. In those instances, sufficient justification will be provided for the variance.

In addition to the structured method of routinely improving the safety of the ammonia refrigeration system, Cold-Link Logistics Hattiesburg is always open to suggestions from employees and contractors regarding methods of improving safety. In general, openness in communication is extremely valuable to Cold-Link Logistics Hattiesburg. By strategically and routinely working toward increased levels of safety, Cold-Link Logistics Hattiesburg strives to maintain the safest ammonia refrigeration system as possible.
